main_definition: To produce or give as a result, effect, or consequence; to provide or offer something.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To produce or generate a particular result or outcome. Example: The fertile soil yields a bountiful harvest each year.
meanings_and_examples.example: The experiment results yielded unexpected data.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To surrender or give up something, usually under pressure or compulsion. Example: During the negotiations, he finally yielded and agreed to the terms.
To be effective in achieving a desired result; to produce results as intended. Example: The new marketing strategy yields impressive sales growth.
meanings_and_examples.example: The medication yields quick relief from pain.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To comply with or conform to requirements, expectations, rules, etc. Example: She must yield to the officer's request during traffic stops.
meanings_and_examples.example: Drivers are required to yield to pedestrians at crosswalks.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To give way; move aside or retreat from an obstacle, opponent, etc. Example: The chess player had to yield his queen in order to avoid a checkmate.
meanings_and_examples.example: The hiker had to yield when the trail was blocked by fallen trees.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To give or supply generously; be abundant or prolific. Example: The rainforest yields an astonishing variety of plant and animal life.
meanings_and_examples.example: The farm yields enough crops to feed the local community.
